STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 19, 2019
Isabella County DHS
1919 Parkland Drive
Mount Pleasant, MI 48858
RE: License #: CP370201201
Isabella County DHS
1919 Parkland Drive
Mount Pleasant, MI 48858
Dear Ms. Prabucki:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 2/20/19.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and ISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP. The corrective action plan is due
15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
James B. Gale, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 296-4814
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP370201201
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768

Name of Facility: Isabella County DHS
Facility Address: 1919 Parkland Drive
Mount Pleasant, MI 48858
Facility Telephone #: (989) 772-8400
Original Issuance Date: 01/01/1992
Service Types:

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 2/5 – 2/20/19

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Three of thirteen service plans reviewed were late. One plan
was 2 days late. One plan was 5 days late and one plan was 25
days late. A corrective action plan is required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.33(c) Page 28 Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the caseworker’s supervisor, the
parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall include an explanation
of the steps taken to involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to
secure their participation in services.
In two of thirteen services two participating parents signed their PATPs more than 30
days after the completion of the service plan. One child over the age of 14 signed his
service more than 30 days after the completion of the plan. SWC did document that the
assigned case manager did engage the caregivers and child in service plan development.
A corrective action plan is required. This is a repeat citation from the 2018 renewal
inspection.
ISEP 6.18 Page 23 Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment 54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative foster parents within 180 days
of the date of placement.
One of three licensed relative homes was licensed in more the 180 days after the child
was placed in the home. A corrective action plan is required.
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational
statewide automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be
the primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
4

The agency was unable to upload all required documents into MiSACWIS. A corrective
action plan is required. This is a repeat citation from the 2018 renewal inspection.
3.Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements except
for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C Page 2 Required Participation in Development - Foster
Parent / Caregiver
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver to meet the specific
individual needs of the child placed in their home are included in the PATP. The foster
parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP process. The foster parent/caregiver
signature is required and indicates that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and
agrees to the activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care. Additionally,
the PATP details the services and activities provided by the foster care worker to assist
the foster parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
In two of thirteen service plans reviewed the caregivers signed their PATPs more than 30
days after the completion of the service plan. This is a repeat citation from the 2018
renewal inspection. A corrective action plan is required.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-6H – Page 7 Unannounced Home Visit CASEWORKER
CONTACT WITH CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in the caregiver’s home each
calendar month. If there are two caregivers, such as a primary and secondary caregiver,
the caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the secondary caregiver in the
home at least once each quarter. The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to
the home every quarter. The unannounced visit must be documented in MiSACWIS.
In two of thirteen service plans reviewed the required unannounced home visit was not
completed. It should be noted that monthly visits were completed as announced. A
corrective action plan is required. The is a repeat citation from the 2018 renewal
inspection.
DHHS Policy 722-06B page 1-7 Family Team Meeting
. Goal Change.
Type Time Frame
Case Plan Development/Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP) within 14 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
5

due date.
In one of thirteen service plans reviewed a family team meeting was not completed as
required. A corrective action plan is required.
.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
DCWL Analyst report
The DCWL analyst between the dates of 10/23/18 and 11/2/18 visited three foster
homes and one unlicensed relative home. The analyst interviewed four foster parents,
two unlicensed relative providers, six children and three birth parents. The following
concerns were identified by the analyst during these visits.
Safety and concern alert #1
1.There are 7 children under the age of 18 in the home. Is there a variance in place for
the number of children in the home that discusses how this number of children are
safe?
2. One birth parent does not feel supported by the assigned worker. The birth parent
feels the worker is no longer working towards reunification.
3. One birth parent is not involved in medical decisions and decisions about her
children's physical appearance.
4. One birth parent is not notified of appointments for her children.
CPA resolution
1.A PER was verbally approved by the director on 5/21/18 at 5:15 pm as this was an
after-hours removal situation. The subsequent PER was entered in the system and
supports the reasons why this met the wellbeing of these children. Specifically, it would
keep the children together. It was closer to the parents, the FC family has strong
community ties with a lot of supports, the FC mom is an Early Head Start teacher with a
degree in Child Development and the FC father has community involvement with
children in coaching sports. They have significant knowledge on child development and
behavior. (PER screen shot are attached.)
2. The birth mother has made minimal progress and has been advised by the
department that a goal change is recommended, and a petition will be filed. This
decision is in conjunction with other service providers working with the family.
Regardless of this the department is continuing to work with her and provide ongoing
services. The birth mother participates in baby court which is more intensive than a
regular FC case.
6

3. The birth mother is advised of her children’s medical needs and involved in decisions.
Uploaded in the documents section are releases signed by the birth mother. Including a
release signed through listening ear dated 12/13/18. The birth mother was aware of the
request for tonsillectomy and signed the consent for the procedure 10/4/18. This is
uploaded in MiSACWIS.
4. The birth mother is advised regularly of her children’s appointments through text
messages. The most recent one notified her of the rescheduled thyroid appointment set
for 12/12/18 at 3:30. As indicated above she has been asked for consent on multiple
occasions and informed of the appointments.
Safety and concern alert #2
1. Foster parents are not notified regularly of training opportunities.
2. Foster home has had one unannounced home visit in a year. The foster home does
not receive quarterly unannounced home visits.
3. One child in the home is exhibiting aggressive behaviors in school and may need
special educational services.
4. One birth parent has not had a case worker visit to their home or where they are
living, during the year-long foster care case.
CPA resolution
1.The CPA identified that this FC parent had inadvertently been left off the email group
for training notifications. We contacted her, apologized for the error and have since put
her on and she is in the communication loop. We also cross checked the other foster
parent emails as a result to assure everyone is getting the training information that is
sent out monthly.
2. Documented unannounced visits in MiSACWIS occurred on 2/14/18 and 5/22/18.
3. Foster care worker documented in the education performance section regarding this
topic. The child was displaying behavior problems in school but is now reported to be
doing much better. His behaviors are graded on a color scale, the child is receiving
good colors every day now.
4. Visits are documented in MiSACWIS occurring at the mother’s residence on
12/14/17, 2/22/18, 3/30/18, 4/30/18, 6/28/18, and 7/24/18. After July the mother
reported to be homeless and couch surfing.
Safety and concern alert # 3
No concerns
Safety and concern alert # 4
1.The family has not participated in a family team meeting.
7

CPA resolution
1.It is documented in MiSACWIS that parent participated in an FTM on 8/7/18.
However, the form is not uploaded in the system to verify signatures and worker at the
time no longer works for this agency for clarification. The relative caregivers will be
invited to the next one.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted an acceptable corrective action plan for the violations
found in the renewal inspection. The agency’s compliance with the 2018 corrective
action plan is detailed below under the 2018 renewal inspection.
2/9/18 Renewal Inspection
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Two of six reevaluations reviewed were not completed 15 days
before the expiration of the license. One reevaluation was
complete on 10/12/17 and the license expired on 10/13/17. One
reevaluation was not complete and the licensed expired on
12/27/17.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with the
corrective action plan to address this citation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
. (1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in
the agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as
soon as is indicated, based on the information received,
but not later than 7 calendar days after receipt of the
information.
One of three special evaluations reviewed was not initiated
within 7 calendar days after receipt of the information. The
8

agency directed the assigned case manager to look into the
complaint when received. This consultant advised the agency
to open a special evaluation.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with the
corrective action plan to address this citation.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(6) Service plans shall be signed by the social services worker
and the social services supervisor.
Three of thirteen service plans were not signed by the case
manager or the supervisor. The case manager did not sign two
plans and the supervisor did not sign one plan.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with the
corrective action plan to address this citation.
ISEP 6.49 – Page 34 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care provider shall receive the
child’s Medical Passport, which must contain the information required by MCL
722.954c(2) and DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, an
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the “Medical Passports”
section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by
the Monitors) and provided to the foster care provider.
In four of eight cases reviewed there was no documentation that the medical passport
was updated quarterly as required.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with the corrective action plan to
address this citation.
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational statewide
automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the primary
tracking system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
In each foster care record reviewed there was at least one document not uploaded into
MiSACWIS. The agency was provided technical assistance on this requirement in the
2017 annual review.
9

This interim inspection found that the agency was not able to upload all required
documents into MiSACWIS.
ISEP 6.33(c) Page 28 Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the caseworker’s supervisor, the
parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall include an explanation
of the steps taken to involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to
secure their participation in services.
Three of thirteen service plans were not signed by the supervisor and case manager. The
supervisor did not sign one service plan and the case manager did not sign two service
plans. This is also a violation of R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with the corrective action plan to
address this citation.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Caseworker contacts
This renewal inspection reviewed eight records where unannounced visits are required.
In two children’s records the required unannounced visits were not completed. In one
record an unannounced visit was not completed during one service plan period. In one
record an unannounced visit was not completed during two service plan periods. This is
a repeat violation from the last two inspections.
This interim review found that in two of thirteen service plans the required unannounced
visit was not conducted.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C Foster care parent agency treatment plan
For both ISP and USP the PATP must be signed by the worker, supervisor, parents,
foster parents and children 14 years and older.
This renewal inspection eight records were reviewed. In six of thirteen service plans the
parent’s signature on the PATP was more than 30 days beyond the end of the service
plan period. In six of thirteen service plans the care giver’s signature on the PATP was
more than 30 days beyond the end of the service plan period. This is a repeat
violation from 2017 annual and 2016 renewal inspection. It should be noted,
however, that the citations for 2016 and 2017 found the PATPs were not signed.
This interim inspection found in two of thirteen service plans the caregiver signed their
PATPs more than 30 days after the completion of the service plan. SWC did document
that the assigned case manager did engage the caregivers in service plan development.
10

DHHS Policy FOM 722-09 USP supervisory approval
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the report date.
This renewal inspection reviewed thirteen service plans. There were three USPs that
were not signed timely. One USP was not signed and two USPs were signed 16 days
and 38 days late. This is a repeat violation from the 2017 annual inspection.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with the corrective action plan to
address this citation.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
.
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
3/19/19
________________________________________
James B. Gale Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 9, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
